resources.string: Artist name information to be stored under the artist tag in the file\'s exif
Do you want to set the ISO of edited rolls to the default ISO of the selected film stock?
Do you want to clear the ISO of edited rolls as well?
Copyright information to be stored under the copyright tag in the file\'s exif
Text file with the roll\'s data in csv format

Add custom aperture values to supplement the predefined list of available aperture values. Custom aperture values will be available for selection when adding new frames with this lens. Only positive values can be added.
An error occurred while exporting the files.
Error while editing picture\'s EXIF data
Text file containing the ExifTool commands
"If you are using the ExifTool stand-alone executable, you can define its path here ending with '/' or '\\' depending on your OS."
Export complementary pictures as a compressed .zip file
Export SQL database as a .db file

NOTE: Exporting the SQL database does not export any complementary pictures attached to frames. \n\nIf you wish to export complementary pictures as well, this needs to be done separately with the \'Export complementary pictures\' option in settings.
File ending of the files you wish to tag (e.g. .jpg or .tiff etc.)
Film stock is in use. Delete anyway?

Setting a fixed lens will change the camera into a fixed-lens camera. The lens will be used by default for all (new) frames added with this camera. This reduces the number of steps when adding new frames and keeps the list of separate lenses to a minimum.\n\nSetting a fixed lens removes and disables other lens links for this camera. You can however define compatible filters for fixed lens cameras.
Focal length values must be zero or greater
You have location updates enabled in the app\'s settings, but GPS is disabled in system settings.\n\nDo you want to go to system settings to enable GPS?
Keep updating the current location using GPS.
Adds -m option to the ExifTool commands to ignore minor errors and warnings when writing EXIF information.
Import complementary pictures from a previously exported .zip file

NOTE: If you are importing complementary pictures from a previous device for example, you should import the .db database file first. 

When complementary pictures are imported, Exif Notes looks for matches between the filenames of imported pictures and frames' details in the current database. 

Imported pictures, which have no matching frames, are discarded.
Import SQL database from a previously exported .db file

Are you sure you want to continue importing? 

This will replace the current database with the imported one. Orphaned complementary pictures will also eventually be removed from storage. 

IMPORTANT! The imported database file must be in exactly the same format as the exported file. If structural changes have been made to the database file or the file is otherwise corrupted, the import will fail! In this case the old database will be used.
Importing complementary pictures, please wait.\n\nDepending on the size of the .zip file, this can take several minutes.
Min aperture cannot be greater than max
Min focal length cannot be greater than max
Min shutter speed cannot be greater than max
No frames to show on map
No make or model was set!
One end of the aperture range was empty!
One end of the shutter range was empty!
Progress notification for complementary pictures export
Progress notification for complementary pictures import
The app needs write permission to external storage to export the .csv file and ExifTool commands.
Picture was set but the file could no longer be found
"If the picture files you want to edit are in a certain folder, you can define its path here ending with '/' or '\\' depending on your OS."

Exif Notes does not collect or use your data outside your own device. Beyond the information Google provides to developers that you can decide to provide (e.g. bug/crash reports), it uses no third-party analytics or advertising frameworks.\n\nThe application can track your location if you give it the appropriate permissions, but the location data is not collected or stored outside the user\'s own device. Exif Notes uses the Google Geocoding API to translate between coordinates and addresses as well as the Places API to get search autocomplete suggestions. Queries to the APIs are done over a secure connection (HTTPS).
This camera is set as a fixed lens camera, but it has other lens mappings. Do you want to remove these mappings?
This lens has compatible camera mappings. Do you want to remove these mappings? No cameras or lenses will be deleted, only the links between them.
Select a lens to add filters.
Started exporting complementary pictures. Check notifications for progress.
Started importing complementary pictures. Check notifications for progress.
Tap on map to move marker
Frame not added. The frame count cannot be greater than 100.

GitHub repository 
https://github.com/tommi1hirvonen/ExifNotes

Updates in this version: 

-Mark roll as favorite 
-Categorize rolls with labels 
-Library updates 
-Code and project refactoring

v1.21.0 2024-02-24: 
-Mark roll as favorite 
-Categorize rolls with labels 
-Library updates 
-Code and project refactoring 

v1.20.2 2024-01-01: 
-Bug fixes 
-Library updates 

v1.20.1 2023-10-14: 
-Bug fixes 
-Themed app icon support 
-Library and SDK updates 
-Targeting Android 14 

v1.20.0 2023-03-17: 
-Implemented JetPack Navigation component 
-Some landscape and tablet specific layout resources 
-Search result autocomplete suggestions when editing a frame's location (Google Places API) 
-Other minor UI changes 
-Bug fixes 
-Code refactoring 

v1.19.0 2023-03-03: 
-Rolls can be exported/shared in JSON format 
-Custom aperture values can be added to lenses 
-Frames can have custom shutter speed values 
-Cameras have a default film format 
-Negative frame counts are available when editing frames (starting from -3) 
-Exported files are selected during export and not in settings 
-Other small improvements 
-Code refactoring 

v1.18.5 2023-02-19: 
-Bug fixes 

v1.18.4 2023-02-12: 
-Bug fixes 
-Minor UX enhancements 

v1.18.3 2023-01-22: 
-Bug fixes 
-Library updates 

v1.18.2 2023-01-20: 
-Decreased UI text, padding and margin sizes 

v1.18.1 2023-01-15: 
-Bug fixes 
-Added link to GitHub repository to About dialog 

v1.18.0 2023-01-02: 
-Major code refactoring 
-Material 3 theming 
-Updated app icon 
-Library and build tool updates 
-Replaced deprecated methods 

v1.17.1 2022-07-21: 
-Library and build tool upgrades 
-Replaced deprecated classes and methods 
-Included comprehensive open source license notices for used dependencies 
-Released source code under the GNU General Public License (GPLv3) 

v1.17.0 2022-01-06: 
-Fixed lens cameras: you can now add/edit fixed-lens cameras in gear settings. When adding frames with a camera that has a fixed-lens, you cannot select a lens in the frame's properties. The lens settings from the camera will be applied when adding new frames or editing existing frames. Filters can be linked to fixed-lens cameras in the gear settings. 
-Replaced deprecated API/method calls, code refactoring 
-Library updates 

v1.16.1 2021-04-29: 
-Fixes a bug which caused B (bulb) to be incorrectly preselected as the shutter speed value for new frames if previous frame's shutter speed value was empty 

v1.16.0 2021-04-11: 
-Replaced deprecated AsyncTasks with Kotlin coroutines 
-New frame batch edit options 
-Frames can be copied 
-Library and dependency updates 
-Code refactoring 

v1.15.0 2020-12-24: 
-Migrated all Java source code to Kotlin 
-General code refactoring 
-Enabled links in About and Help dialog 
-Roll status is displayed in the list of rolls (loaded/unloaded/developed) 
-UI improvements 
-Moved the about and help dialogs from the overflow menu to settings 

v1.14.2 2020-06-09: 
-Changed date and time format from yyyy-M-d H:m to yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm for a prettier appearance 
-Frame counts can be reversed when batch editing frames (useful for prewind cameras) 
-If the frames activity is being resumed, the user does not need to unlock the device with authentication 
-Replaced deprecated API calls 
-Bug fixes 
-Migrated large portions of source code from Java to Kotlin 

v1.14.1 2020-04-25: 
-Rolls can be marked as unloaded and developed with date and time 
-Reserved characters are now escaped appropriately when exporting a csv file 
-When editing a frame's location, the marker can be moved to the current location with a press of a button 
-Film stocks can be filtered based on their type or developing process 
-Bug fix: Filter and Location data are now separated with a comma in cvs files 
-Bug fix: Flash and LightSource tags are now written using text values instead of integers 

v1.14.0 2020-01-23: 
-Added flash used and light source properties to frames 
-Added film stock property to rolls and a database of preadded film stocks 
-Rolls can be batch edited 
-Improved roll UI element presentation 
-Visible rolls can be filtered when displaying all rolls on map 
-Minimum supported Android version raised from 4.0.3 (Ice Cream Sandwich) to 5.0 (Lollipop) 
-Replaced deprecated API calls and improved compatibility with Android 10 (Q) 

v1.13.1 2019-10-12: 
-Updated deprecated location API calls 
-Targeting Android 10 (Q) 
-Migrated from Android Support Library to AndroidX 
-Data structure classes migrated from Java to Kotlin 

v1.13.0 2018-10-21: 
-Database overhaul: added foreign key references and removed some not-null constraints 
-Frames can have multiple filters 
-Rolls can be added without specifying a camera 
-Fixed deprecated Google Maps Geocode API calls 

v1.12.0 2018-07-16: 
-Bug fixes 
-UI improvements 
-Frame's aperture value can now be manually overridden for custom aperture values (e.g. f/0.95 and f/1.7) 
-Exposure compensation increments are now camera specific (third stop or full stop) 

v1.11.0 2018-04-08: 
-You can now add a complementary picture to a frame using the phone's camera or the gallery application. Pictures are saved in a compressed format (max 1024px on longest side) and can be exported/imported in the app's settings. Individual pictures can also be added to the gallery application in the frame edit window. 
-Bug fixes 

v1.10.1 2018-03-20: 
-UI improvements 
-Fixed bug which prevented from batch editing frames' locations. 
-Fixed bug which caused app to crash on pre L devices when batch editing frame counts upwards. 

v1.10.0 2018-03-17: 
-Select multiple frames or rolls by long pressing on a frame or roll. 
-Batch edit frames by selecting multiple frames and then pressing the edit icon. Batch edit options so far are frame count and location. 
-UI improvements 
-Performance improvements 
-Bug fixes 

v1.9.5 2018-02-18: 
-Added ability to archive film rolls by long pressing on rolls and marking them as archived (or active to return them to an active state). Visible rolls can be filtered in the film roll view by pressing on the filter icon (only active/archived rolls or all rolls). 
-Dialog prompting to go to settings to enable GPS is only shown, if location updates are enabled in the app's settings. 

v1.9.4 2017-11-18: 
-In ExifTool commands, the frame count is now preceded by *_ to ensure, that only correct frames are being updated by ExifTool. Make sure you use underscore as the delimiter before the frame count in your filenames. 
-Ensured compatibility with Android O. 
-Moved the aperture and shutter speed properties higher up in the frame edit dialog because these properties are changed frequently. 
-Added option to app's settings to ignore minor errors and warnings when writing EXIF information with ExifTool. 

v1.9.3 2017-05-15: 
-Focal length is now selected using a seek bar instead of a scroll wheel 

v1.9.2 2017-05-01: 
-Bug fix: 'Show on map' caused app to crash on some phones 

v1.9.1 2017-04-30: 
-Bug fix: formatted address is now added to a frame automatically 

v1.9.0 2017-04-30: 
-Frame can now have a formatted address. If no address is found, coordinates are displayed instead. 
-Support for diacritics in ExifTool commands 
-Map type (normal, satellite etc.) can be changed whenever map is shown 

v1.8.1 2017-04-20: 
-Bug fixes 

v1.8.0 2017-04-18: 
-Bug fixes 
-UI updates 
-Frames can be edited from the map 
-Map displays more information about frames 

v1.7.3 2017-04-14: 
-Bug fixes 
-Added a dark theme option 
-Added new tags: 
			-ImageDescription 
			-DateTimeOriginal 

v1.7.2 2017-03-30: 
-Fixed a bug which rejected valid database imports 

v1.7.1 2017-03-27: 
-No app relaunch needed after database import 
-Bug fixes 

v1.7.0 2017-03-25: 
-Bug fixes 
-Special characters are now allowed when entering text anywhere in the app. 
-Filters can now be added to the database and frame's information. 
-Shutter speed and aperture increment are now camera and lens specific respectively instead of global settings. 
-Lenses now have an aperture range, focal length range and aperture increment setting. 
-Cameras now have a shutter speed range and a shutter speed increment setting. 
-Rolls now have ISO, push/pull and format attributes. 
-Frames now have focal length, exposure comp, no. of exposures and filter attributes. 
-The user can now export and import the entire database as a .db file. This is useful when you want to transfer all your data to a new phone for example. 
-Changes to ExifTool commands: file names can now have a prefix before the frame number and the user can now choose in the settings which file ending should be used. 

v1.6.0 2016-10-13: 
-The app now requires write permissions to the phone's external storage (see third bullet point) 
-The app can now share two text files when exporting a roll's data: one contains the data in csv format and the other contains the ExifTool commands. The user can choose which files to export in the app's settings 
-Added the possibility to export the csv file and/or ExifTool commands using an inbuilt folder browser (Export files to storage). This feature requires write permissions to the phone's external storage. 
-Location info is added to a frame only if the user has enabled location updating in the app's settings 
-Added a help/quick guide to the app to set up Exif Notes to work with ExifTool 
-Added version history to the About dialog 

v1.5.1 2016-09-13: 
-Fixed bug: the app no longer crashes when picking a location for a frame when the location is empty and the device is rotated 

v1.5.0 2016-08-17: 
-Added sorting functionality to both the rolls list and frames list 

v1.4.1 2016-08-14: 
-Fixed bug: the keyboard no longer blocks the Notes field when editing a roll's or frame's information 

v1.4 2016-05-30: 
-Fixed broken ExifTool command export. However, exporting a .csv is currently disabled 

v1.3 2016-05-18: 
-Bug fixes 

v1.2 2016-05-18: 
-UI improvements 
-Ability to export frames as a .csv file 
-Ability to add cameras and lenses when adding new rolls and frames 
-Performance improvements 
-Bug fixes 

v1.1 2016-03-20 (beta): 
-ExifTool command creation 
-Camera and lens now contain make and model 
-Minor improvements 

v1.0 2016-03-13 (beta): 
-First published version

This is a quick guide to help you set up Exif Notes so that you can tag your scanned files on your computer using ExifTool. Please visit the homepage of ExifTool by Phil Harvey for more information on how to use ExifTool: 
http://exiftool.org 

1. First you should define the artist name and copyright information in the app's settings. These can be anything, name, company, year etc. 

2. You should define the \’ExifTool path\’ in the app's settings if you haven\’t placed it in your PATH file. For example, \’~UserName/Documents/Image-ExifTool-10.13/\’ (without the apostrophes). That is to say the ExifTool executable is in a folder called Image-ExifTool-10.13 in the user's Documents folder. 

3. Then you should define the \’Path to pictures\’ in the app's settings, for example \’~UserName/Desktop/\’ (without the apostrophes). That is to say the scanned files are on the user's desktop. 

4. By default the image file ending used when creating the ExifTool commands is .jpg. You can change this to any possible file ending in the 'File ending' setting. 

5. Name the scanned files in such a way, that the name ends with an underscore and the frame's number. The number in the file name should correspond to the frame count in the app. The file's ending should be the one you specified in the previous step. These examples are all valid file names: 2016-02-03_1.jpg (frame #1), Example_10.tiff (frame #10), FileName_15.PNG (frame #15) 

6. Export the roll\’s data by clicking the ellipsis when viewing the frames of a roll and then click \’Export/share files\’ to share them via another app (Dropbox or Gmail for example) or alternatively click 'Export files to storage' to export the files using an inbuilt folder browser. This exports one or two text files (depending on which files the user has chosen to export in the app's settings), one containing the rolls data in csv format and the other containing the ExifTool commands. 

7. Open the text file containing the ExifTool commands on your computer. Copy the commands for the files you wish to tag and paste them on your terminal. Make sure you run all the commands, you may have to press enter to run the last command. 

8. ExifTool will run and update the exif tags of your scanned files. The updated tags are listed below: 
-Artist 
-Copyright 
-Make 
-Model 
-LensMake 
-LensModel 
-Lens 
-DateTime 
-DateTimeOriginal 
-ShutterSpeedValue 
-ExposureTime 
-ApertureValue 
-FNumber 
-UserComment 
-ImageDescription 
-GPSLatitude 
-GPSLatitudeRef 
-GPSLongitude 
-GPSLongitudeRef 
-ExposureCompensation 
-FocalLength 
-ISO 
-SerialNumber 
-LensSerialNumber 
-Flash 
-LightSource
